utterances: Are we, in fact, the liberal media?
I don't know.
Carl, are you the liberal media?
I don't think so.
I have--I keep applying to the liberal media.
I have a problem.
I cannot get into either the liberal media or the worldwide Jewish conspiracy.
And its bothering me, frankly, because I think there are benefits, there are membership cards—I believe there are discounts to be had.
And nobody will let me in.
Here's what I say: people sometimes complain to us because they say you always make fun of the Republicans.
And I--when are you going to make fun of the Democrats?
And I always say the same thing.
I say, if you would be so kind as to elect a Democrat to anything of importance, I would be happy to make fun of that person at that time.
And then they say, okay, thanks.
And I say, you should have been around when Bill Clinton was president.
I think the president has had his fill of comedians after last weekend.
No, we're very excited because our guest at tomorrow night's show, at the GW University Lisner Auditorium is Mayor Anthony Williams, of D.C.
And I know you're a baseball fan…
Absolutely.
…so I'm going to tell you, it's going to be all Nationals for the whole hour.
And the Lerner Group should be announced by then.
The Lerner Group.
That's great.

That's the question, isn't it?
Well $450 million for the team, so, even major commercial real estate developer might be a little strapped to come up with money for a relief pitcher at this point.
I know!
Anyway.
Peter Sagal and Carl Kasell of NPR's WAIT, WAIT DON'T TELL ME!
Which is heard on many of these NPR stations.
Thanks so much for coming around.
Good luck with the show.
Thank you, Neal.
Good to be here.
Thank you, Neal.
I'm Neal Conan.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Three years ago today, American war planes began a campaign that signaled the start of the Iraq war.
The air bombardment was followed by the invasion of Iraq by the U.S.-led coalition and the overthrow of Iraq's dictator, Saddam Hussein.
NPR's Anne Garrels was one of sixteen American journalists to stay in Baghdad during the bombing.
About half an hour ago, a little more than that, we heard air raid sirens wailing across the city.
Then we heard a lot of anti-aircraft guns.
It was very noisy...
Anne's decision to stay in Iraq was based in large part on the trust she had in her Iraqi driver and translator, Tahir Younis.
She sat down with him to recall those days and the three years that have elapsed.
When we were working together during the war, did you trust me?
Anne, it was difficult because, in general, yes.
But I get some instruction to collect some information about you.
You are an American intelligence...
That's what they told you?
Yeah.
From CIA.
To monitoring you and to watching you.
But you protected me, many, many times.
I think because you are with the media.
Okay?
You are in the middle between the Iraqi government and the U.S.
Army.
And we did become close.
We became very close friends.
Yes, and I'm am proud on this.
The bombing turned out to be much less than Tahir feared.
But U.S.
forces reached the capital much faster than he anticipated.
As the Marines arrived at the Palestine Hotel and helped pull down the statue of Saddam Hussein, Tahir wept.
He was humiliated.
Because not-Iraqi people, they collapse the statue.
Saddam regime should be destroyed by Iraqi people, not the U.S.
Army.
They should do it by themselves if they are brave, but Iraqi people showed all the world they are not brave.
Three years in, what's the situation now?
How would you describe it?
Of course, it's growing worse.
Not what was expected.
You see, it's not difficult for America as a superpower, England and the other countries, to rebuild electricity stations or to provide Iraq with the new equipment.
Three years very long time, they can't do it.
Do people think that the U.S.
has deliberately not done this?
Yes.
And by intention.
They don't want to do it.
What's it like to live in your neighborhood?
We lost the security.
We can't sleep well because, for many things.
Bombing, searching our houses by, either by U.S.
Army, it was before maybe more than one years, and sorry, they have very bad reputation, because they destroyed doors, the furniture, because of nothing.
We lost our freedom.
Are the Iraqi police and the National Guard any better than the Americans now that they're taking over certain parts of the city?
No, it's much worse.
We live in civil war.
So, if the Iraqi Army or the Iraqi police came and all of them from Shia, and they followed me as a Sunni, I will go to the hills.
Last year, Tahir decided that despite the continuing U.S.
occupation, he wanted to serve his country.
He'd been a major in the Iraqi Army until Saddam's commanders fired him for refusing what he calls illegal assignments.
However, when he got to the new interior ministry, it was clear everyone was afraid of infiltration by insurgents and Shiite militias.
They are afraid to give their real address.
So nobody put his real address.
Nobody.
Even those recommendation don't put their, your real address.
Because the police didn't trust the other policemen.
Yes.
Yeah, believe me.
What else.
There is another item in the form, what is your, I think there is no word in English, it is Iraqi word, called medhet(ph).
Are you Sunni or Shiite?
So this is unbelievable.
Nobody accepted.
Let me just ask you.
I mean, you're from Ramadi.
You're a Sunni.
Do you, you know, none of us really know who the insurgents are.
Do you think members of your family could be in the insurgency?
Yes.
Why not?
Does anybody tell each other what they're doing?
No. No. Even between the brothers.
No trust.
Have you ever had a good experience with the American military?
Before we heard or the rumors came that the U.S.
Army steal money from the houses, gold from the houses.
For me, I didn't believe at that time, until I get this experience.
